newsitem.title: TURKEY: Turkey plans rise in wheat import tax.
newsitem.headline: Turkey plans rise in wheat import tax.

text.p: Turkey, which presently applies a 15 percent tax on imported wheat, plans to raise the import tax rate in an effort to protect wheat producers, senior officials said on Thursday.

"To protect the farmers we definitely need to slow the imports," said one farm official. "The plan to raise the import tax rate is being considered by the foreign trade undersecretariat now," he told Reuters.

A foreign trade official said he could not specify the new rate but "work has almost been completed and the decree will be submitted to the cabinet either today or tomorrow." The decree would take effect after the cabinet has approved it.

The farm official said the need to increase the tax arose following Turkey's initial estimates that it would produce around 18 million tonnes of wheat in 1997/98, up from 16.5 million tonnes a year ago.
"But the farmers should be protected against imports," he said.
Flour millers estimated that Turkey had an carry-over stock of two million tonnes from 1996/97.
"There will not be a supply problem this year but imports will continue despite an expected slowdown because of the planned tax rise," said Ilker Tanik, head of the Millers' Association.
Trade officials said the tax rise would only be in wheat and "wheat-related grain". Taxes for other grains including barley would remain the same at 15 percent.
